_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The City of Albany, Texas (City) operates the new 2.5 MGD Water Treatment Plant (WTP) which is located in Shackelford County, Texas.  The Albany WTP produces potable water for the City of Albany, as well as for Fort Griffin Special Utility District. This is a new ultra-filtration WTP.  The new plant is currently in start-up.  Chlorine gas is used in the disinfection process at this new plant.  Up to 10,000 pounds of chlorine may be stored at the new Albany WTP. Because the stored quantity of chlorine onsite exceeds the threshold quantity for chlorine (A?68.130; Table 1), the City developed this Risk Management Plan (RMP).  The Albany WTP is subject to Program 2 RMP requirements (A?68.12(c)).  A Management System overseen by the City's Treatment Superintendant is implemented to ensure that the RMP and associated Prevention Program are implemented correctly and maintained up-to-date.

The Prevention Program designed to prevent accidental releases includes all required elements of 40 CFR Part 68.  The TCEQ licensing program for water operators is used as a training tool, along with site-specific RMP training.  TCEQ licensing testing and on-site observation and demonstration are used to evaluate comprehension of all training materials.  Written operating procedures are used in conjunction with on-the-job training to ensure that certified WTP operators are proficient in performing their duties before being allowed to work with chlorine storage and feed systems.  Certified WTP operators conduct daily inspections and any problems with the chlorine systems are corrected and documented.  In addition, the certified WTP operators ensure that the equipment used in the disinfection process is maintained according to the manufacturers' recommendations (A?68.56(a)).  This is a new WTP; therefore, there is no history of a chlorine release that resulted in an injury, either on-site or off-site, within the previous five (5) years (A?68.42(a)).  As part of the Program, the City will p

eriodically perform compliance audits, hazard reviews and incident investigations, according to a predetermined schedule described in the RMP and as needs dictate.  These compliance audits and hazard reviews document any planned changes to improve safety (A?68.50 & A?68.58).

The Albany WTP complies with the emergency response regulations per Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) 29 CFR A?1910.38, as well as with applicable fire codes and the standards set forth by the Chlorine Institute.  The Albany WTP is a non-responding facility for emergency response.  The Albany WTP operators are trained to notify the City's Fire Department via call to 9-1-1 in the event of a release from the Albany WTP.  The City of Albany's Fire Department will serve as the first responder and coordinate the emergency response according to the county-wide Emergency Response Plan, including the evacuation of surrounding residents when required (A?68.90(b)).
